results.title: Paris 1900: Chronique de 1900 a 1914
results.brief_description:
This is a montage of archival footage, newsreels and photographs evoking the political, social and artistic life of Paris at the turn of the century. The ironic tone of the narration underlines the contradiction between the sweetness of the period and the cataclysm of World War I. Personnalities appearing include: Gustave Eiffel, Marcelle Linder, Liane de Pougy, Caroline Otero, Cleo de Merode, Colette, la Comtesse d’Uzes, Buffalo Bill, Charles Pathe, Ferdinand Zecca (Pathe), Ferdinand Zecca, Andre Gide, Paul Valery, Guillaume Apollinaire, Louis Bleriot, Felix Mayol, Maurice Chevalier, Mistinguett, Polin, Sarah Bernhardt, Polaire, Jean Mounet-Sully, Leon Bonnat, Auguste Renoir, Claude Monet, Auguste Rodin, Leon Tolstoi, Jean Jaures, Aristide Briand, Leon Blum, Arthur Meyer, Maurice Barres. Includes segments from ‘Ceux de chez nous’ directed by Sacha Guitry. Reference: Forum des Images. http://www.vdp.fr

Credits: Producer, Pierre Braunberger ; director, writer, Nicole Vedres ; music, Guy Bernard ; assistant director, Alain Resnais ; editor, Yannick Bellon.
Cast: Claude Dauphin [narration].

results.title: Juliette et L'air du Temps = Juliet and the Feel of the Time
results.brief_description:
Eighteen-year old Juliette who grew up in a rural area in France has come to Paris to live. She scrapes by through begging, lives in a condemned building, and steals food occasionally at supermarkets. Her boyfriend would like her to settle down and get married, but Juliette seems to enjoy this hand-to-mouth existence.

Credits: Producer, Michel Chanderli ; director, Rene Gilson ; writer, Rene Gilson ; photography, Walter Baal ; music, Bernard Gilson.
Cast: Agnes Chateau, Jacques Zanetti, Mathieu Volta, Fabienne Arel, Janine Molinier.

results.title: L'argent des Autres = Other People's Money
results.creator_credit: Christian de Chalonge, Adolphe Viezzi, Henri Lassa and Michelle de Broca
results.brief_description:
Henri Rainier, a bank director, is unwillingly implicated in a financial fraud and laid off. Convinced he is being set up by others in the bank, he decides to investigate a number of dubious transactions and discovers a vast real estate swindle. Awards: Prix Louis Delluc, 1978 ; French Academy of Cinema (Cesars) 1978: Best Director for Christian de Chalonge, Best Film.

Credits: Producers, Michelle de Broca, Henri Lassa, Adolphe Viezzi ; director, Christian de Chalonge ; writers, Pierre Dumayet, Christian de Chalonge ; photography, Jean-Louis Picavet ; music, Patrice Mestral.
Cast: Jean-Louis Trintignant, Claude Brasseur, Michel Serrault, Catherine Deneuve, Juliet Berto, Francois Perrot.

results.title: Papa, les Petits Bateaux = Papa the Little Boats
results.brief_description:
Venus de Palma (also known as Cookie) is a tough, sweet little rich girl, and is rather smart, too. She is smart enough and charming enough to outwit her kidnappers by setting one against the other until they have all killed each other or died trying to prove their worth to her. Kaplan was a journalist and assistant to Abel Gance before starting to make her own films, including several shorts on painters. She has also written surrealist/erotic novels under the name of Belen, and worked for television. Her claim to fame is her firts feature ‘La fiancee du pirate/Dirty Mary’ (1969), a key film in early femisnist film debates. (…) Kaplan subsequent films have been less successful, perhaps because her libertarian sensitivity became outmoded, but they have been consistently interesting if not controversial: for instance ‘Nea’ (1976), an attempt at soft porn from a woman’s point of view, and ‘Plaisir d’amour’ (1991), a tale of three women (grandmother, mother and daughter) who exhaust a man sexually.’ Reference: Ginette Vincendeau. ‘The companion to French cinema’. London: BFI Publishing, 1996

Credits: Director, Nelly Kaplan ; writers, Nelly Kaplan, Claude Makovski, Rene Guyonnet ; photography, Ricardo Aronovich ; music, Andre Popp.
Cast: Sheila White, Michel Bouquet, Judith Magre, Jean Paredes, Sydney Chaplin, Michel Lonsdale, Pierre Mondy, Catherine Allegret.

results.title: L'alibi = the Alibi
results.brief_description:
A Parisian dance hostess, blackmailed into providing an alibi for a murderer falls in love with a secret police agent sent to win her trust. Other thrillers of the period were as sharply directed and written, but few had the inestimable advantage of the sparks between Stroheim’s killer and Jouvet’s police chief. ‘L’alibi’ is stylistically and thematically the closest of his [Chenal] films to the work of Carne and Prevert, he all but abandoned his habitual moving camera, while multiplying (studio shot) expressionistic effects of lighting and composition. Chenal has the dubious distinction of being the major filmmaker of the decade (1930s) most thoroughly forgotten by the film community after WWII for reason from which prejudice may not, perhaps, be excluded.” Reference: Alan Williams. “Republic of Images: a history of French filmmaking”. Harvard University Press, 1992.

Credits: Producer, Joseph Nash ; director, Pierre Chenal ; writers, Marcel Achard, Jacques Companeez, H. Juttke ; photography, Ted Pahle ; music, Georges Auric.
Cast: Louis Jouvet, Erich von Stroheim, Albert Prejean, Jany Holt, Margo Lion, Max Dalban, Maurice Bacquet, Roger Blin, Florence Marly, Margo Lion.

results.title: Voyage En Grande Tartarie = Trip Through Purgatory
results.brief_description:
Unhinged by the murder of his wife by a madman dressed as a cowboy, Alexis hops into his car and lays himself wide open for a number of adventures; some of them are heavenly, but most of them are harrowing in the extreme. Along the way he meets a suicidal emigre and brings her along his complicated journey.

Credits: Producer, Marin Karmitz ; director, Jean-Charles Tacchella ; writer, Jean-Charles Tacchella ; photography, Andre Dubreuil ; music, Gerard Anfosso.
Cast: Jean-Luc Bideau, Micheline Lanctot, Lou Castel, Catherine Verlor, Catherine Laborde.

results.title: Gueule D'amour = Lady Killer
results.brief_description:
Lucien Bourrache, colonial soldier stationed in Orange, is a lady’s man. While on a business trip to Cannes, Lucien meets Madeleine. Lucien accepts to lend money to Madeleine that she later looses at the gambling table. Although Lucien is smitten by Madeleine, she rejects him. Lucien returns to Orange and resigns from the army in order to follow Madeleine to Paris, where he discovers that she is kept by an other man. Raoul Ploquin was at the time in charge of the French section of the German production company UFA. He had Gremillon under contract to film ‘L’Etrange Monsieur Victor’ which was delayed. Ploquin organised the Gremillon-Gabin meeting and filming started soon after at the Neubabelsberg studios and in Orange and Cannes for the exteriors.

Credits: Producer, Raoul Ploquin ; director, Jean Gremillon ; writer, Charles Spaak ; photography, Gunther Rittau ; music, Lothar Bruhne ; assistant director, Louis Daquin.
Cast: Jean Gabin, Mireille Balin, Rene Lefevre, Marguerite Deval, Pierre Etchepare, Jane Marken, Jean Ayme, Robert Casa, Henri Poupon, Pierre Magnier.

results.title: Le Bois des Amants = Lovers' Grove
results.brief_description:
During WWII, Herta von Stauffen travels to Normandy with a fake Ausweiss and a borrowed uniform to be with her husband for Christmas. She is billeted at Madame Parisot’s whose son, Charles, has joined the British army.

Credits: Producer, Ray Ventura ; director, Claude Autant-Lara ; writers, Albert Husson, Rene Hardy, Jacques Remy ; photography, Jacques Natteau ; music, Rene Cloerec ; art direction, Max Douy.
Cast: Laurent Terzieff, Erika Remberg, Francoise Rosay, Horst Franck, Gert Froebe, Francoise Rosay.

results.title: Marius
results.brief_description:
Marius, who works in his father’s dockside cafe in Marseilles, is set to marry Fanny, his childhood sweetheart. But the call of the sea is too strong for him, and he joins the merchant navy, unware that Fanny is pregnant. The film succeeds best in his portrayal of the little people of Marseilles, their humour and accents. This is the first film of Pagnol’s ‘Marseille trilogy’, followed by ‘Fanny’ (1932) and ‘Cesar’ (1936) [*=Held in our collection].

Credits: Producer, Bob T. Kane ; director, Alexandre Korda ; writer, Marcel Pagnol ; photography, Ted Pahle ; music, Francis Gromon.
Cast: Raimu, Pierre Fresnay, Fernand Charpin, Orane Demazis, Alida Rouffe, Robert Vattier, Marcel Maupi.

results.title: Pour Clemence = for Clemence
results.brief_description:
After losing his job, a 40 year old engineer decides to change the major orientation of his life and become a house husband. But this sudden change in domestic arrangements upsets his wife and daughter.

Credits: Director, Charles Belmont ; writers, Charles Belmont, Marielle Issartel ; photography, Philippe Rousselot ; music, Michel Portal, Jean Schwarz.
Cast: Jean Crubelier, Eva Darlan, Lucia Bensasson, Jacques David, Claude Debord, Jean Deschamps.
